Based on your preference cues, I would recommend two movies from this list: "Elysium" and "The Queen".
Both of these movies are set in the year 2154, where the very wealthy live on a man-made space station while the rest of the population resides on a ruined Earth.
In both of these movies, the main characters face significant challenges in their respective worlds. In "Elysium," the main character, Max Dearden, is faced with significant financial challenges due to his inability to pay his debts. In order to overcome these financial challenges, Max decides to take part in an experimental program known as Elysium.
In "The Queen," the main character, Elizabeth II, is faced with significant political challenges due to her country's ongoing conflict with its neighbor, Iraq.
To overcome these political challenges, Elizabeth II decides to take part in a diplomatic negotiation known as The Negotiator.
Both of these movies feature outstanding performances from their respective casts. In "Elysium," the main actor, Max Dearden, delivers an outstanding performance that brings his character to life. In "The Queen," the main actor, Elizabeth II, delivers an outstanding performance that brings her character to life.

conversation.text: I recommend We the Living as it showcases Ayn Rand's theories of Communism in practice, with three individuals standing out as winners: Kira who wants to be a builder and the two men who love her - Leo an aristocrat and Andrei a Communist in their tensely dramatic story. It's a picture of what dictatorship - of any kind - does to human beings, what kind of men are able to survive, and which of them remain as the ultimate winners. What happens to the defiant ones? What happens to those who succumb? Who are the winners in this conflict? Against a vivid panorama of political revolution and personal revolt, Ayn Rand offers an answer that challenges the modern conscience.
